Staff should advise the client that the matter has been referred to the Police, that the Police may investigate the incident and may want to interview the client and take a statement. The client may choose whether or not to participate in the police investigation.
  • Clients with an intellectual/cognitive impairment/disability or a mental illness must have an independent third person present during any interview. The role of the independent third person is to facilitate communication, ensure that the client understands his or her rights, and to support the client.
  • Police are responsible for arranging the independent third person. Hi Five Community Services staff should not act as the independent third person.
  • Where the alleged victim is under 18 years of age, he or she must have a parent, guardian or an independent person present when a statement is being taken. The role of the independent person is to provide support to the client, and ensure that their evidence is accurately recorded. If the young person has a cognitive disability, then an independent third person rather than an independent person should be present.
  • The police will decide whether or not to proceed with charging.
  • If the matter is taken to court, the client will most likely be required to give evidence.

Support and advocacy

  • The response by staff to a client's disclosure of assault can be central to the client's ongoing safety and their recovery from the trauma of assault. Following an allegation of assault, it is important to:
  • listen to and support the client;
  • reassure the client that they did the right thing by talking about the assault;
  • ensure the client’s, and others’, immediate safety, health and wellbeing needs are met such as obtaining medical attention and referral to other specialist/victim support services;
  • ensure the client's specific support needs are addressed including access to communication aides and resources;
  • tell the client what you plan to do next; and
  • with the client’s consent, engage family, significant others, an independent key support person and/or advocate to support the client and advocate on their behalf.
  • A key support person may include a family member, significant other, or advocate who are independent of the perpetrator and/or service. The role of the key support person is to provide support and advocacy, and ensure client’s rights are respected in relation to any subsequent investigation or action taken. A key support person should be someone who preferably knows the client well and has their trust.
  • Specialist/victim support services may include crisis care, counselling, advocacy, legal information and advice.
  • For clients who are from culturally and linguistically diverse communities or from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, staff should consider referring the client to specialist agencies or staff for additional support. It may also be necessary to arrange an interpreter. Appropriate services may include the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Corporation Family Violence Prevention and Legal Service or the Vic Aboriginal Health Service.
  • Where the client uses a language other than English or is deaf, an interpreter of the same sex as the client should be arranged as soon as practicable to interpret for the client, police and other persons involved in the process. Contact the Interpreting and Translating Service.
  • Some victims may be reluctant to speak to an interpreter because they fear that what they say may be passed on to their local community. In this case, it is possible to request a telephone interpreter from another state, or to not disclose the victim’s name to the interpreter. When using an interpreter directly, consideration should be given to arranging an interpreter who is not associated with the client or his or her immediate cultural community.

Supporting client through the justice process

  • Hi Five Community Services will support clients through the justice process, including police investigation, prosecution and crimes compensation processes as appropriate. This may include:
  • ensuring the client has access to appropriate communication aides and tools to facilitate disclosures and the provision of evidence;
  • ensuring the client has access to a key support person of their choosing;
  • alerting police to the need for an independent third person or independent person and the client's particular communication support needs, and the need for timely interviews to facilitate the recall of information;
  • facilitating arrangements with police for interviews and examination of evidence; and
  • facilitating arrangements with specialist support services.
  • Under no circumstances should anyone but the Police interview the client about the allegation.

Where a client is the alleged perpetrator

  • Staff must consult with Police about whether to inform the client of the report to Police. The police may want to interview the client and take a statement. Clients with an intellectual/cognitive impairment/disability and/or mental illness must have an independent third person present during the interview, and this will be arranged by police. Where the client is under the age of eighteen years, an independent person must be present during the police interview.
  • Staff must contact the service most directly responsible for the client’s care who will ensure that the client has legal representation and is assisted during the investigation and hearing.
  • Under no circumstances should anyone but the Police interview the client about the allegation. It is acknowledged however that some discussion with the client may be required to establish safety and a basic understanding of what has occurred.

Notification of next of kin or guardian – all clients

  • If the alleged perpetrator is the client’s next of kin or legal guardian, the staff member must ensure that the immediate needs of the client and an appropriate planned response are undertaken.
  • The Directors must notify the client’s next of kin or guardian where:
  • the client is under 18 years old;
  • the client is over 18 years old and consents to their next of kin or guardian being contacted. If the client is unable to make an informed decision regarding contact and the client does not have an appointed guardian, Hi Five Community Services Coordinator should contact the next of kin as appropriate;
  • the client has a legal guardian;
  • The client is on a guardianship to Secretary order
  • The Directors must explain to the next of kin or guardian: the nature of the allegation; the standard procedure for reporting allegations to the Police; that the client may choose whether or not to participate in the Police investigation; and any action taken by staff since reporting the allegation.
  • If the client is a child or young person who does not wish their next of kin or guardian to be notified, a decision in relation to notification will need to consider factors including the client’s age and capacity, where they are living and their best interests. If necessary, legal advice should be sought, and if a decision is taken not to notify the next of kin or guardian, this must be clearly documented and placed on the client’s file.

Ongoing support

  • Irrespective of gender, victims of sexual assault frequently experience negative outcomes including dissociation, posttraumatic stress disorder, depression and anxiety. Victims of physical assault also frequently experience shock, numbness, fear, depression and anxiety. In recognition of this, after an allegation of abuse, additional support and/or a review of supports provided to the client may be required.
  • A quality of support review must also be undertaken by a Director for clients who are victims or alleged perpetrators of an assault. Agreed actions for the client’s immediate and ongoing needs must be recorded on the client’s care plan. This must include:
  • steps being taken to assure the client’s safety and wellbeing in the future
  • treatment or counselling the client may access to address their safety and wellbeing
  • modifications in the way services are provided (for example, same gender care or placement)
  • how best to support the client through any action the client takes to seek justice or redress including making a report to Police
  • any ongoing risk management strategy required where this is deemed appropriate.

External Reporting

  • The Director/s must report any allegation or assault of a person with a disability to the NDIS Commission, and when doing so, should refer to the Department’s Critical Client Incident Management Instruction to determine when a report is required and how to complete the report.
  • The Department has established a protocol for the provision of client incident reports relating to allegations of staff to client assault or unexplained injuries within disability services to the Disability Services Commissioner for independent monitoring, review and advice on client specific issues and trends.
  • The Department also has an established protocol with the Commission for Children and Young People for the provision of client incident reports for children in out of home care. The Commission monitors critical incidents reports to identify any emerging or recurring themes, trends and issues.

Staff and client debrief and support

  • After a serious and traumatic incident, it is likely that high levels of stress will be experienced by those connected with the incident.
  • In relation to a sexual assault, the local CAVIC can provide assistance with debriefing and secondary consultation.
  • General arrangements to support staff may include allocating a safe place for retreat, giving staff the option of being immediately and temporarily relieved of their duties, providing communication with families and offering to organise transport home.
  • General arrangements to support clients may include allocating a safe place for retreat and communicating with families.
  • Clients have a right to complain about Hi Five Community Services services and they and their key support person/advocate should be alerted to Hi Five Community Services’ Feedback, Compliments and Complaints Policy and Procedure and external complaints bodies.

Where a staff member is the alleged perpetrator

  • After reporting to the Police, the Directors must be immediately notified of the report.
  • Depending on the nature of the allegation, the Directors’ response regarding the alleged perpetrator should comply with Hi Five Community Services’ Human Resources Policy and Procedure. Responses include redirecting the staff member to alternate duties that do not involve direct client care, standing the staff member down and/or reporting them to the Disability Worker Exclusion Scheme Unit.

Where a staff member is the alleged victim

  • Allegations or assaults where a Hi Five Community Services staff member is the alleged victim should be dealt with in accordance with Hi Five Community Services’ Incident Management Policy and Procedure.

Monitoring and Review

  • Hi Five Community Services’ service delivery and satisfaction surveys will assess:
  • client and other stakeholder awareness of their rights and the extent to which they feel able and supported to exercise them;
  • client and other stakeholder satisfaction with Hi Five Community Services’ complaints processes; and
  • the extent to which clients feel safe and protected in their dealings with Hi Five Community Services.
  • Hi Five Community Services’ Continuous Improvement Plan will be used to record and monitor progress of any improvements identified. 
  • This Policy and Procedure will be reviewed at least annually by Hi Five Community Services’ Management Team. This process will include a review and evaluation of: current practices and service delivery types and locations; the Incident Register; policies and procedures; the Complaints and Grievances Register; and, will incorporate staff, client and other stakeholder’s feedback.

Endorsement Date: 15 Jan 2020

Last Review Date: 10 Jan 2020

Next Review Date: 15 Jan 2021

This policy and procedure will be reviewed at least annually and changes endorsed by the Management Team.

fields.options:
1.7 CHILD SAFE POLICY AND PROCEDURE AND STATEMENT OF COMMITMENT

Purpose and Scope

The purpose of this policy, procedure, and statement of commitment is to demonstrate Hi Five Community Services’ commitment the safety of the children in its care.

Legislation, regulations and standards relevant to this policy and procedure include, but are not necessarily limited to:

  • National Disability Insurance Scheme Act 2013
  • National Disability Insurance Scheme (Provider Registration and Practice Standards) Rules 2018 [F2020C00051]
  • Disability Inclusion Act 2018
  • NDIS Practice Standards and Quality Indicators – Provision of Supports - Safety

Organisational documents relevant to this policy and procedure:

  • Human Resources Policy and Procedure
  • Participants Charter
  • Feedback, Compliments and Complaints Policy and Procedure
  • Records and Information Management Policy and Procedure
  • Privacy and Confidentiality Policy and Procedure
  • Risk Management Policy and Procedure
  • Participants Incident Management Policy and Procedure

This policy and procedure applies to all potential and existing participants, their family members, carers and other supporters, as well as all staff of Hi Five Community Services.

Hi Five Community Services’ Commitment to Child Safety

Hi Five Community Services is committed to child safety.

Hi Five Community Services wants children to be safe, happy and empowered. We support and respect all children, as well as our staff.

Hi Five Community Services is committed to the safety, participation and empowerment of all children.

Hi Five Community Services has zero tolerance of child abuse, and all allegations and safety concerns will be treated very seriously and consistently with our robust policies and procedures.

Hi Five Community Services has legal and moral obligations to contact authorities when we are worried about a child’s safety, which we follow rigorously.

Hi Five Community Services is committed to preventing child abuse and identifying risks early, and removing and reducing these risks.

Hi Five Community Services has robust human resources and recruitment practices for all staff. Hi Five Community Services is committed to regularly training and educating our staff on child abuse risks.

Hi Five Community Services supports and respects all children, as well as our staff. Hi Five Community Services is committed to the cultural safety of Aboriginal children, the cultural safety of children from culturally and/or linguistically diverse backgrounds, and to providing a safe environment for children with a disability.

Hi Five Community Services has specific policies, procedures and training in place that support our staff to achieve these commitments.

Staff who believe a child is at immediate risk of abuse must phone 000.

 

Policy

This policy and procedure is intended to empower children who are vital and active participants in Hi Five Community Services. Hi Five Community Services involves them when making decisions, especially about matters that directly affect them. Hi Five Community Services listens to their views and respects what they have to say.

Hi Five Community Services promotes diversity and tolerance in our organisation, and people from all walks of life and cultural backgrounds are welcome. In particular, Hi Five Community Services:

  • promotes the cultural safety, participation and empowerment of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children;
  • promotes the cultural safety, participation and empowerment of children from culturally and/or linguistically diverse backgrounds; and
  • ensures that children with a disability are safe and can participate equally.

This policy and procedure guides Hi Five Community Services’ staff on how to behave with children accessing Hi Five Community Services’ services.

All Hi Five Community Services staff must agree to abide by Hi Five Community Services’ Staff Code of Conduct, which specifies the standards of conduct required when working with children. All staff, as well as children and their families, are given the opportunity to contribute to the development of the Code of Conduct.

 

Procedures

Training and supervision

Training and education is important to ensure that everyone in Hi Five Community Services understands that child safety is everyone’s responsibility.

Hi Five Community Services’ culture aims for all staff (in addition to parents/carers and children) to feel confident and comfortable in discussing any allegations of child abuse or child safety concerns. Hi Five Community Services trains staff to identify, assess, and minimise risks of child abuse and to detect potential signs of child abuse.

Hi Five Community Services supports staff through ongoing supervision to develop their skills to protect children from abuse; and promote the cultural safety of Aboriginal and Torre Strait Islander children, the cultural safety of children from linguistically and/or diverse backgrounds, and the safety of children with a disability.

New employees will be supervised regularly to ensure that they understand Hi Five Community Services’ commitment to child safety and that everyone has a role to play in protecting children from abuse, as well as checking that their behaviour towards children is safe and appropriate (please refer to Hi Five Community Services’ Staff Code of Conduct to understand appropriate behaviour further).

Any inappropriate behaviour will be reported through appropriate channels, including the NDIS Commission and Vic Police, depending on the severity and urgency of the matter.

Recruitment

Hi Five Community Services takes all reasonable steps to employ skilled people to work with children. Hi Five Community Services develops selection criteria and advertisements that clearly demonstrate Hi Five Community Services’ commitment to child safety and an awareness of Hi Five Community Services’ social and legislative responsibilities. Hi Five Community Services understands its ethical and legislative obligations when recruiting staff.

Hi Five Community Services actively encourages applications from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, people from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds and people with a disability.

All people engaged in child-related work are required to hold a Working with Children Check and to provide evidence of this Check.

Hi Five Community Services carries out reference checks and police record checks to ensure that it recruits the right people. See Hi Five Community Services’ Human Resources Policy and Procedure for more information on this process.

If during the recruitment process a person’s records indicate a criminal history, the person will be given the opportunity to provide further information and context.

Fair Procedures for Staff

The safety and wellbeing of children is Hi Five Community Services’ primary concern. Hi Five Community Services is also fair and just to staff. The decisions that Hi Five Community Services makes when recruiting, assessing incidents, and undertaking disciplinary action will always be thorough, transparent, and based on evidence.

Hi Five Community Services records all allegations of abuse and safety concerns in accordance with its incident management policies and procedures. All records are securely stored, in accordance with Hi Five Community Services’ Records and Information Management Policy and Procedure.

If an allegation of abuse or a safety concern is raised, Hi Five Community Services provides updates to children and families on progress and any actions that the organisation takes.

Privacy

All personal information considered or recorded will respect the privacy of the individuals involved, whether they be staff, parents or children, unless there is a risk to someone’s safety. Hi Five Community Services has safeguards and practices in place to ensure any personal information is protected. Everyone is entitled to know how this information is recorded, what will be done with it, and who will have access to it, in accordance with Hi Five Community Services’ Privacy and Confidentiality Policy and Procedure.

Legislative Responsibilities

Hi Five Community Services takes its legal responsibilities seriously, including:

  • Failure to disclose: Reporting child sexual abuse is a community-wide responsibility. All adults in Vic who have a reasonable belief that an adult has committed a sexual offence against a child under 16 have an obligation to report that information to the Police;[5]
  • Failure to protect: People of authority in Hi Five Community Services will commit an offence if they know of a substantial risk of child sexual abuse and have the power or responsibility to reduce or remove the risk, but negligently fail to do so;.[6] and
  • Any staff that are mandatory reporters must comply with their duties.[7]

Risk Management

Hi Five Community Services proactively manages risks of abuse to children accessing its services.

Hi Five Community Services has risk management strategies in place to identify, assess, and take steps to minimise child abuse risks, which include risks posed by physical environments (for example, any doors that can lock), and online environments (for example, no staff or volunteer is to have contact with a child supported by the organisation on social media). These strategies will be documented in Hi Five Community Services’ Risk Management Plans, in accordance with its Risk Management Policy and Procedure.

Allegations, concerns, and complaints

Hi Five Community Services takes all allegations seriously and has practices in place to investigate them thoroughly and quickly. Hi Five Community Services staff are trained to deal appropriately with allegations.

Hi Five Community Services works to ensure all children, families, and staff know what to do and who to tell if they observe abuse or are a victim, and if they notice inappropriate behaviour.

Hi Five Community Services staff and stakeholders all have a responsibility to report an allegation of abuse if they have a reasonable belief that an incident took place (see information about Failure to Disclose, above).

If an adult has a reasonable belief that an incident has occurred they must report the incident. Factors contributing to reasonable belief may be:

  • a child states they or someone they know has been abused (noting that sometimes the child may in fact be referring to themselves);
  • behaviour consistent with that of an abuse victim is observed (see Hi Five Community Services’ Participants Incident Management Policy and Procedure);[8]
  • someone else has raised a suspicion of abuse but is unwilling to report it; and
  • observing suspicious behaviour.

Monitoring and Review

This policy and procedure will be reviewed at least annually, or following any significant incident, by the Management Team, and will incorporate participants and other stakeholder feedback.

Hi Five Community Services’ Continuous Improvement Plan will be used to record and monitor progress of any improvements identified.

Hi Five Community Services will review and monitor its commitment to child safety and relevant policies and procedures in accordance with the Internal Review and External Audit Schedule. This schedule includes reviewing service planning and delivery activities, which incorporate participants and stakeholder participation and assesses feedback provided to and by participants and stakeholders.

Service delivery and satisfaction surveys will assess:

  • participants and other stakeholder awareness of their rights and the extent to which they feel safe and supported by Hi Five Community Services; and
  • participants and other stakeholder satisfaction with Hi Five Community Services’ child safety processes.

Endorsement Date: 15 Jan 2020

Last Review Date: 10 Jan 2020

Next Review Date: 15 Jan 2021

This policy and procedure will be reviewed at least annually and changes endorsed by the Management Team.

Hi Five Community Services’ Governance and Management Policies and Procedures describe to its staff, clients and stakeholders how Hi Five Community Services carries out its operational, legal and financial responsibilities in relation to its NDIS and.

They should be read alongside other parts of our policy pack which cover the ways Hi Five Community Services meets NDIS Commission practice standards.

fields.label: 2.1 GOVERNANCE POLICY AND PROCEDURE

fields.options:
Purpose and Scope

The purpose of this policy and procedure is to demonstrate Hi Five Community Services’ commitment to sound governance, and to document how governance is carried out and reviewed within the organisation.

Legislation, regulations and standards relevant to this policy and procedure include:

  • National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) Act 2013 (Cwth)
  • Corporations Act 2001 (Cwth)
  • Accountability Principles 2014
  • NDIS Practice Standards and Quality Indicators – Provider Governance and Operational Management

Organisational documents relevant to this policy and procedure include:

  • Hi Five Community Services Organisational Chart

This policy and procedure applies to all Hi Five Community Services staff, contractors and volunteers.

Definitions

Governance is the process by which organisations are directed, controlled and held to account. It encompasses authority, accountability, stewardship, leadership, directions and control exercised in the organisation[9].

Policy

Hi Five Community Services will proactively listen and provide opportunities to its clients to have in input in policy making and governance of the organisation. This will be achieved by constantly taking feedback from clients and also forming a Participant Representative Group, once we have a sizable client base.

Hi Five Community Services has effective systems and processes in place to guide and support its overall direction, effectiveness, supervision processes and internal and external accountability. Accountable and transparent governance arrangements ensure Hi Five Community Services:

  • complies with relevant legislation, regulations and contractual arrangements;
  • supports and develops its staff; and
  • delivers quality and safe services to its clients.

Procedures

  • Hi Five Community Services will conduct annual client satisfaction survey to capture clients feedback, this information will be used when revising our policies, furthermore, client feedback will captured through regular client feedback, client feedback forms, risk assessments, incident reports, etc and all this information will be used in revising organisational policies and procedures.
  • Hi Five Community Services is a registered business name of the company Hi Five Community Services.
  • Hi Five Community Services operates in accordance with the terms set out in Hi Five Community Services Constitution.
  • Hi Five Community Services’ organisational structure is set out in its Organisational Chart, provided below.

Figure 1. Hi Five Community Services Organisational Chart

Hi Five Community Services’ Management Team consists of both Directors and the Senior Manager.

Roles & Responsibilities These roles will be filled as the business is approved by NDIS Commission and as our customer base grows.

  • CEO

The role of the CEO is to provide Leadership and Governance to the organisation. To deliver upon the Goals and Objectives set out in the Strategic Vision Plan document and the annual business plan. The CEO is responsible for overseeing any customer complaints and ensuring the organisation is complying with the Disability Inclusion Act 2018 and NDIA Rules of business. Detailed responsibilities of this role are listed in its Position Description document.

  • COS Business Manager

The role of the COS Business Manager is to support National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) Participants to achieve their NDIS Plan goals, by coordinating informal, mainstream and funded supports. COS Business Manager supervises the COS Team Leader and conducts regular meetings with COS TL to keep track of the work progress of all COS. Detailed description of this role is included in its Position Description Document.

  • Business Manager

High level duties include: Oversee the Operations department and provide leadership to the team, inputting in the three years strategic vision document, annual business planning, preparing monthly management reports, co-responsible for DSW rostering with HR Co-ordinator, responsible for operational compliance of The organisation, managing participants/families’ concerns and complaints, assist CEO in marketing The organisation and meeting new Participants and their families to welcome them to The organisation introduce to them company services and vision. Detailed description of this role is included in its Position Description Document.

  • Plan Manager

Plan Manager is responsible for looking after the plan management function for the company. Plan Manager leads the team of accountants who look after the individual client’s accounts. All the accountants/bookkeepers report to the Plan Manager Detailed description of this role is included in its Position Description Document.

  • Accountant / Bookkeeper

High level duties include: responsible for accounts receivable and accounts payable functions, maintain clients plan management spreadsheets, payroll processing, General Ledger maintenance, and support Plan Manager as required. Detailed description of this role is included in its Position Description Document.

  • Care Coordinator

High level duties include: Managing Disability support workers rosters (work with Business Manager), maintaining staff training and development, maintaining staff compliance register (police check, WWC check, policy awareness and NDIS Worker Screening checks), screening applications for new staff, dealing with staff complaints, organising staff annual performance reviews and processing leave forms. Detailed description of this role is included in its Position Description Document.

  • Training And Development Coordinator

High Level duties include: Developing formalised training procedures in conjunction with the Business Manager. Providing on the job training, completing various reports to comply with regulations, engage with students from secondary school and colleges, carry out annual performance reviews of the staff etc. Detailed description of this role is included in its Position Description Document.

  • Support Co-ordinator

Works collaboratively with other Support Coordinators within the team, and management. Actively participates and engages in team meetings and initiatives Assists with problem solving and addressing any emergent issues. Identifies any communication or workflow issues and makes suggestions for improvement. Works towards goals and accepts guidance and direction from team leader and management. Detailed description of this role is included in its Position Description Document.

  • Individual Counsellor

High level duties include: Intake and assessment of individuals seeking psychological services, provision of centre-based and outreach counselling interventions, participation in the development and facilitation of groups, Writing reports and updating on client’s outcomes and goals achieved etc. Detailed description of this role is included in its Position Description Document.

  • COS Team Leader

COS team leader leads the team of support coordinators. The support coordinators manage different clients and reports to the COS Team leader. The COS team leader looks after the daily activities related to the Coordination of support and reports directly to the COS Business manager. Detailed description of this role is included in its Position Description Document.

  • Disability Support Workers

High level duties include: implementing training and support services aimed at maximising the living, employment, social and recreational skills of people with a disability, community inclusion, independence, decision making, and personal choice should be promoted through these supports, with a focus on individual needs. Detailed description of this role is included in its Position Description Document.

  • Casual, Part time or Full time permanent employment may be offered as the business grows.
  • All staff other than the Directors will be employed under the Social, Community, and Disability Services Industry Award 2010 (MA00010) or Health Professionals and Support Services Award 2010 (MA000027).
  • Collectively, the Management Team is expected to have the qualifications and experience to deal with issues relating to financial and legal matters, human resources, service management and service promotion.
  • The Directors will report to the Management Team on a quarterly basis, based on regular reporting regarding: program delivery; financial management, data and IT management and service performance, quality and compliance (including client feedback and complaints).
  • In recognition that stakeholder participation in Hi Five Community Services’ governance and management processes will improve service outcomes, Hi Five Community Services will seek feedback on its governance from stakeholders (clients, families, carers, advocates, staff, other service providers or government representatives) regularly (see Hi Five Community Services Feedback, Compliments and Complaints Policy and Procedure).
  • Service delivery will be tracked in Hi Five Community Services’ client management system, which will support and streamline organisational reporting. Hi Five Community Services’ performance will be summarised on a yearly basis in its Annual Report.

Delegation of Responsibility

The following delegations have been developed and agreed by the governing body to be in place. This delegation table will assist in running the business without disruption in absence of a key personnel.

Competence of Governing Body

Hi Five Community Services will be governed by a competent team of management staff. Our governing body will follow the Corporate Governance Framework as developed by AICD. One of the quadrants of this framework requires our management to continuously update their knowledge and skills and improve on their experiences.

Like all staff, the governing body will also be required to do a self-assessment of knowledge and skills gap annually and will be required to prepare an individualised development plan to continuously improve competency.

Conflict of Interest

  • Failure to respond to actual or potential conflicts of interest can damage the reputation of and community confidence in Hi Five Community Services. It may also have legal ramifications.
  • When making decisions, staff should consider:
  • Do I have any personal or private interests in a matter that may conflict or be perceived to conflict with my duties in the organisation?
  • Could there be a benefit for me, my family or friends into the future if I involve myself in a matter?
  • How will my involvement be viewed by others? 
  • Does my involvement in the decision being made appear fair and reasonable?
  • All staff should avoid any conflict arising between their personal interests (or the interests of any other related person or body) and their duties to Hi Five Community Services.
  • Staff must not take advantage of their position to gain, directly or indirectly, a personal benefit, or a benefit for any associated person (e.g. a family member or another organisation).
  • Staff must not make use of inside information.
  • The personal interests of staff, and those of any associated persons, must not be allowed to take precedence over those of Hi Five Community Services generally.
  • Staff should seek to avoid conflicts of interest wherever possible. Full and prior disclosure of any conflict, potential conflict, or the appearance of a potential conflict, must be made to the Management Team. Once the conflict has been declared, the Management Team must decide what action to take to manage the conflict.

Co-ordination of Supports / Plan Management and Conflict of Interest

  • One of the guiding principles Hi Five Community Services adheres to is: “Quality and Professionalism – we will maintain high standards of quality services and governance”. We understand as Support Coordinators and Plan Managers there may be a conflict of interest when delivering clients direct services and Support coordination/ Plan Management. Hi Five Community Services truly believes in underlying principles of NDIA to offer choice and control to the participants.
  • Our policy is that we will not offer core supports or capacity building supports to the clients who receive support co-ordination services from us to avoid any conflict of interest.
  • Furthermore, to eliminate any conflict of interest, as support coordinators we will offer at a minimum of 3 service providers to the clients, whether its Core supports or Capacity Building / Capital supports. The client will be given the choice and control to pick the service provider they wish to receive supports from. The client will be introduced to these services providers so they can meet them and understand their services, vision and mission. The client will be fully supported in making independent decision and whichever service provider they wish to proceed with we will support them in their decision.
  • Given the above, if the support-coordination client still wishes or insists to receive core and capacity building supports from us. We will respect their decision and their choice. We will record the evidence of offering multiple choices to the client and the reason why they insisted on receiving core/ capacity building supports from us.

Monitoring and Review

  • This policy and procedure will be reviewed three-yearly by Hi Five Community Services’ Management Team and incorporate staff, client and other stakeholder feedback.
  • Hi Five Community Services’ annual client satisfaction surveys will assess satisfaction with Hi Five Community Services’ governance processes and provide opportunity for feedback on areas for improvement.
  • Hi Five Community Services’ Continuous Improvement Plan will be used to record and monitor progress of any improvements identified and where relevant feed into Hi Five Community Services’ service planning and delivery processes.

Endorsement Date: 15 Jan 2020

Last Review Date: 10 Jan 2020

Next Review Date: 15 Jan 2021
