Racial discrimination - Discrimination on the basis of race, colour, descent or national or ethnic origin and in some circumstances, immigrant status.

Sex discrimination – Discrimination on the basis of sex, marital or relationship status, pregnancy or potential pregnancy, breastfeeding, family responsibilities, sexual orientation, gender identity or intersex status.

Sexual harassment - any form of unwanted, unwelcome or uninvited sexual behaviour that is offensive, humiliating or embarrassing.

Workplace harassment - repeated behaviour, other than behaviour amounting to sexual harassment, of one employee or group of staff members that is unwelcome, unsolicited and considered to be offensive, intimidating, humiliating or threatening by another staff member.

Policy

  • Hi Five Community Services strives to provide a positive working environment in which all staff are valued and encouraged to contribute.
  • As an equal opportunity employer, the organisation is bound by all relevant State and Federal legislation in relation to equal employment opportunity (EEO). This legislation ensures that no employee will be discriminated against unfairly or unlawfully.
  • Hi Five Community Services’ staff are expected to comply with equity and anti-discrimination legislation, Hi Five Community Services’ Staff Code of Conduct and this policy and procedure.

Procedures

  • Hi Five Community Services’ work practices and processes are continuously reviewed to ensure they comply with EEO requirements. These work practices include: 
  • recruitment and selection;
  • pay and benefits;
  • training and development;
  • promotion;
  • discrimination and harassment;
  • performance appraisals/reviews;
  • grievance procedures; and
  • terminations.

Discrimination

  • Hi Five Community Services staff must neither be discriminated against, nor discriminate or treat unfairly or unlawfully another staff or community member on the following grounds:
  • sex;
  • race, colour, nationality or ethnic origin;
  • religion;
  • disability;
  • age;
  • pregnancy;
  • marital or parental status;
  • political belief or activity;
  • trade union activity;
  • lawful sexual activity; or
  • gender neutral
  • association with or relation to a person with any of the above attributes.

Harassment

  • Staff must not be subject to or engage in unlawful harassment or discrimination against another staff or community member. 
  • Forms of harassment include: 
  • sexual harassment;
  • homosexual and transgender vilification;
  • HIV/AIDS vilification; and
  • racial vilification.
  • Sexual harassment includes:
  • unwanted attention or touching;
  • sexual propositions;
  • leering or staring;
  • offensive language;
  • displaying nude images;
  • persistent requests for dates; and
  • crude or offensive jokes.
  • Harassment will not be tolerated and disciplinary action will be taken against those responsible in accordance with Hi Five Community Services’ Human Resources Policy and Procedure.

Inclusive language

  • When writing internal or external documents, staff must ensure that non-sexist and non-racist language is used by:
  • avoiding male-dominated terms (e.g. use ‘chair’ or ‘chairperson’ instead of ‘chairman’);
  • eliminating the unnecessary use of the person’s gender (e.g. ‘female Manager’);
  • avoiding the use of ‘he’ or ‘she’ (use ‘their’ instead of ‘his’ or ‘her’).

Breaches of this policy and procedure

  • All breaches of this policy and procedure will be taken seriously. 
  • Employees who feel they are the subject of discrimination or harassment should:
  • approach the Directors to discuss appropriate actions or options; or
  • lodge a formal complaint or grievance which will be dealt with by the Directors in accordance with Hi Five Community Services’ Disputes and Grievances Policy and Procedure.
  • Complaints will be dealt with promptly and in accordance with relevant State and Federal legislation and Hi Five Community Services policies and procedures.
  • All complaints will remain confidential.

Monitoring and Review

  • This policy and procedure will be reviewed at least two-yearly by Hi Five Community Services’ Management Team. This process will include a review and evaluation of the Complaints and Grievances Register; and, will incorporate staff, client and other stakeholder’s feedback
  • Hi Five Community Services’ Continuous Improvement Plan will be used to record and monitor progress of any improvements identified and where relevant feed into Hi Five Community Services’ service planning and delivery processes.

Endorsement Date: 15 Jan 2020

Last Review Date: 10 Jan 2020

Next Review Date: 15 Jan 2021

This policy and procedure will be reviewed at least 2-yearly and changes endorsed by the Management Team.

fields.label: 2.14 DISPUTES AND GRIEVANCES POLICY AND PROCEDURE

fields.options:
Purpose and Scope

The purpose of this policy and procedure is to set out the steps Hi Five Community Services staff are required to take in regards to disputes and grievances.

Legislation, regulations and standards relevant to this policy and procedure include:

  • NDIS Practice Standards and Quality Indicators – Provider Governance and Operational Management
  • National Disability Insurance Scheme Act 2013
  • National Disability Insurance Scheme (Complaints Management and Resolution) Rules 2018 [F2018L00634]

Documents relevant to this policy include:

  • Hi Five Community Services’ and NDIS Staff Code of Conduct
  • Hi Five Community Services’ Equity, Anti-Discrimination and Workplace Harassment Policy and Procedure

Disputes and grievances raised by Hi Five Community Services staff, volunteers and contractors would generally be dealt with under this policy and procedure, however, from time to time staff may raise issues or provide feedback that is best dealt with under Hi Five Community Services’ Feedback, Complaints and Dispute Resolution Policy and Procedure (see Part 2 of this manual).

This policy and procedure applies to all Hi Five Community Services staff, contractors and volunteers.

Definitions

Dispute – a disagreement or argument that can arise from discrimination, harassment or any other behaviour between staff members or between the organisation and a staff member.

Grievance - a formal complaint lodged by one staff member against another or against the organisation.

Sexual harassment - any form of unwanted, unwelcome or uninvited sexual behaviour that is offensive, humiliating or embarrassing.

Workplace harassment - repeated behaviour, other than behaviour amounting to sexual harassment, of one employee or group of staff members that is unwelcome, unsolicited and considered to be offensive, intimidating, humiliating or threatening by another staff member.

Policy

  • Hi Five Community Services is committed to maintaining positive working relationships between its employees and management. Disputes and grievances should be addressed within the organisation in a timely and confidential manner.

Procedure

General

  • Problems can arise from the behaviour, action or decisions of management or other staff.
  • Disputes and grievances must be treated by all parties with the utmost confidentiality, and the complainant must not be victimised.
  • All grievances must be taken seriously and investigated in an impartial manner. 

Disputes

  • Staff should attempt to resolve disputes with the other person involved before lodging a grievance.
  • If attempts to resolve the dispute fail, staff must discuss the matter with their supervisor.
  • The supervisor will mediate and seek an acceptable compromise for both parties.
  • Where staff are employed, if the dispute involves their supervisor, the staff member must discuss the matter with the Directors (or delegate).
  • Issues of sexual harassment or discrimination should be brought to the notice of the Directors.

Formally lodging grievances

  • If a dispute cannot be resolved, the staff member should lodge a grievance in writing to the Directors. 
  • This should detail:
  • description of the decision/s or behaviour/s that are the subject of the dispute;
  • the manner in which the decision or behaviour has adversely affected the staff member;
  • the time and date of the decision/s or behaviour/s;
  • names of witnesses;
  • attempts made to resolve the dispute; and
  • the action the staff member deems necessary to resolve the grievance.

Investigating grievances

  • Once a formal grievance is lodged, the Directors (or delegate) will investigate the matter within five working days.
  • If a Director has a conflict of interest in the matter, the alternative Director will conduct the investigation.
  • The following parties will be interviewed:
  • the employee who lodged the grievance;
  • the employee against whom the grievance has been lodged;
  • any witnesses; and
  • the relevant supervisor(s).

Resolving grievances

  • Where necessary, the Directors will:
  • appoint an independent mediator to help resolve disputes; and
  • encourage support person, union or professional association representation and involvement in dispute resolution procedures.
  • If the investigation reveals that the grievance is valid, and depending on the nature of the complaint and its seriousness, the employee against whom the grievance was lodged may be:
  • required to apologise to the employee who lodged the grievance;
  • given a written warning, counselling, transfer or demotion; or
  • dismissal.
  • If the grievance cannot be substantiated because of a lack of evidence, the organisation may:
  • remind all employees of their obligations under the Code of Conduct and Hi Five Community Services’ Equity, Anti-Discrimination and Workplace Harassment Policy and Procedure;
  • ask all employees to undertake training in negotiation skills and dispute resolution;
  • ask supervisors to identify potential conflicts among their employees and offer counselling.
  • If the grievance is found to be a frivolous claim, and depending on the seriousness of the allegations, the employee making the complaint may be:
  • asked to undertake counselling;
  • make a written apology to the employee complained about;
  • given a written warning, transfer or demotion; or
  • dismissed.
  • Staff have the right to appeal decisions relating to disputes. Appeals should be directed in writing to the Directors and a final decision will be made by the Management Team. Staff who successfully appeal will have the outcome and actions reassessed for appropriateness. Staff who are not successful in their appeal will have the original decision reconfirmed.

Monitoring and Review

  • This policy and procedure will be reviewed at least two-yearly by Hi Five Community Services’ Management Team and incorporate staff (where applicable), client and other stakeholder feedback.
  • Hi Five Community Services’ Continuous Improvement Plan will be used to record and monitor progress of any improvements identified and where relevant feed into Hi Five Community Services’ service planning and delivery processes.

Endorsement Date: 15 Jan 2020

Last Review Date: 10 Jan 2020

Next Review Date: 15 Jan 2021

This policy and procedure will be reviewed at least 2-yearly and changes endorsed by the Management Team.

fields.label: 2.15 RETURN TO WORK POLICY AND PROCEDURE

fields.options:
Purpose and Scope

The purpose of this policy and procedure is to set out the steps Hi Five Community Services follows in an instance where a Director or staff member are injured during the course of employment.

Legislation, regulations and standards relevant to this policy and procedure include:

  • National Disability Insurance Scheme Act 2013
  • NDIS Practice Standards and Quality Indicators – Provider Governance and Operational Management
  • National Disability Insurance Scheme (Practice Standards – Worker Screening) Rules 2018 [F2018L00887]
  • Workplace Injury Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2013

Documents relevant to this policy include:

  • NDIS Staff Code of Conduct
  • Hi Five Community Services’ Occupation Health and Safety Policy and Procedure
  • Hi Five Community Services’ Human Resources Policy and Procedure
  • Hi Five Community Services’ Equity, Anti-Discrimination and Workplace Harassment Policy and Procedure

Policy

  • Hi Five Community Services is committed to the return to work of its injured workers and will:
  • prevent injury and illness by providing a safe and healthy working environment; and
  • participate in the development of an injury management plan and ensure that injury management commences as soon as possible after the work is injured; and
  • support the injured worker and ensure that early return to work is a normal expectation; and
  • provide suitable duties for an injured worker as soon as possible; and
  • ensure that injured workers (and anyone representing them) are aware of their rights and responsibilities – including the right to choose their own doctor and approved workplace rehabilitation provider, and the responsibility to provide accurate information about the injury and its cause; and
  • consult with staff and, where applicable, unions to ensure that the return to work program operates as smoothly as possible, and
  • maintain the confidentiality of injured worker records, and
  • not dismiss a worker as a result of a work related injury within six months of becoming unfit for employment.

Procedures

Notification

  • Carer for Life’s Directors (or delegate) will notify record all injuries in the Register of Injuries
  • The Directors (or delegate) will notify WorkSafe Vic of all injuries to staff within 48 hours. 

Recovery

  • The Directors (or delegate) will ensure that the injured worker receives appropriate first aid and/or medical treatment as soon as possible.
  • The Directors (or delegate) will consult with the doctor nominated by the injured worker and who is responsible for the medical management of the injury and assist in planning return to work.

Return to work

  • The Directors (or delegate) will arrange a suitable person to explain the return to work process to the injured worker.
  • The Directors (or delegate) will ensure that the injured worker is offered the assistance of a WorkCover approved workplace rehabilitation provider if it becomes evident that they are not likely to resume their pre-injury duties, or cannot do so without changes to the workplace or work practices.
  • The Directors (or delegate) will arrange for the worker’s early return to work (subject to medical and rehabilitation provider advice).

Suitable duties

  • Hi Five Community Services’ Directors (or delegate) will develop an individual return to work plan when the worker according to medical advice, is capable of returning to work.
  • Hi Five Community Services will provide suitable duties that are consistent with medical advice and that are meaningful, productive and appropriate for the injured worker’s physical and psychological condition, depending on the individual circumstances of the injured worker. Suitable duties may be:
  • at the same worksite or a different worksite;
  • the same job with different hours or modified duties;
  • a different job;
  • full time or part time.

Dispute resolution

  • Hi Five Community Services will work together with the injured worker and their union representative to resolve any disagreements about the return to work program or suitable duties
  • If disagreements cannot be resolved, Hi Five Community Services will involve other parties such as the worker’s treating doctor, the agent/insurer, an approved workplace rehabilitation provider or an injury management consultant.

Monitoring and Review

  • This policy and procedure will be reviewed at least two-yearly by Hi Five Community Services’ Management Team. This process will include a review and evaluation of: current practices and service delivery types and locations; the Incident Register; policies and procedures; the Complaints and Grievances Register; and, will incorporate staff, client and other stakeholder’s feedback.
  • Hi Five Community Services’ Continuous Improvement Plan will be used to record and monitor progress of any improvements identified and where relevant feed into Hi Five Community Services’ service planning and delivery processes.

Endorsement Date: 15 Jan 2020

Last Review Date: 10 Jan 2020

Next Review Date: 15 Jan 2021

This schedule will be reviewed at least 2-yearly and changes endorsed by the Management Team.

fields.label: 2.16 MAINTENANCE AND MANAGEMENT OF EQUIPMENT, FURNITURE, LIGHTING AND VENTILATION POLICY AND PROCEDURE

fields.options:
Purpose and Scope

This policy and procedure sets out the practices to be followed in order to maintain goods, equipment, furniture, lighting and ventilation at Hi Five Community Services’ premises.

Legislation, regulations and standards relevant to this policy and procedure include:

  • National Disability Insurance Scheme Act 2013
  • National Disability Insurance Scheme (Provider Registration and Practice Standards) Rules 2018 [F2020C00051]
  • Occupational Health & Safety Act 2004 (VIC)
  • Occupational Health and Safety Regulations 2017 (Vic)
  • Occupational Health and Safety Amendment Regulations 2014 (Vic)
  • Workplace Injury Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2013
  • AS/NZS 4804:2001 and 4801:2001 Work Health and Safety Systems
  • NDIS Practice Standards and Quality Indicators – Provider Governance and Operational Management

Organisational documents relevant to this policy and procedure include:

  • Hi Five Community Services Work Health and Safety Policy and Procedure
  • Hi Five Community Services Work Health and Safety Improvement Register
  • Hi Five Community Services Incident Management Policy and Procedure
  • Hi Five Community Services Workplace Inspection Checklist
  • Hi Five Community Services Maintenance Book

This policy and procedure applies to all Directors, staff (where applicable), volunteers and contractors. It should be read in conjunction with Hi Five Community Services’ Work Health and Safety Policy and Procedure.

Definitions

Maintenance falls into three broad categories:

Essential Maintenance – work that is recurrent in nature, required to keep systems operational, safe and as required by statutory authorities or regulation, for example:

  • fire protection systems;
  • security systems;
  • ventilation systems;
  • heating and cooling plant and equipment;
  • lift services;
  • electrical equipment safety inspections and testing; and
  • hazardous materials management.

Planned Maintenance – work that has been identified through asset inspection and assessment procedures required to be undertaken to preserve a building’s fabric including features, for example:

  • painting previously painted surfaces;
  • replacement of floor coverings;
  • replacement of furniture;
  • annual cleaning; and
  • gutter cleaning.

Unforeseen Maintenance – work that cannot be anticipated, usually as a result of a breakdown or an accident, which is essential for health safety, security or protecting the environment, for example:

  • blocked drains from stormwater or sewerage;
  • electrical hazards; and
  • vandalism.

Policy

The built and landscaped environments at Hi Five Community Services will be kept in such condition to ensure that the facilities are adequate:

  • for the services provided;
  • for the numbers of clients supported; and
  • for safe and secure use by staff, clients and other stakeholders.

Procedures

  • The Directors will formally inspect Hi Five Community Services’ premises on a six-monthly basis using Hi Five Community Services’ Workplace Inspection Checklist, in accordance with Hi Five Community Services’ Internal Review and External Audit Schedule. The checklist refers to:
  • chemicals;
  • electricity;
  • storage;
  • equipment;
  • furniture;
  • floor coverings;
  • ventilation;
  • lights;
  • fire extinguishers; and
  • evacuation.
  • The Directors will take necessary corrective action to ensure any unacceptable condition or risk situation is resolved, and service delivery is not impacted.
  • Hi Five Community Services also has a Maintenance Book located at its premises. Staff will record any items that require maintenance in this book. The Directors will engage an external maintenance person to attend to these issues. If the matter is of an urgent manner, a tradesman will be notified immediately.
  • If a maintenance issue is identified and it poses an immediate threat, and/or this issue impacts the routine delivery of service (e.g. equipment that is essential when supporting clients such as a mobility device), staff, clients and stakeholders must notify the Directors (or delegate) immediately.
  • The Directors will develop Risk Management and Risk Treatment Plans relating to fire safety, building and equipment maintenance and security systems. The Directors will review these on a monthly basis and report on relevant risks to the Management Team. Identified risks will be tracked by the Directors using Hi Five Community Services’ Risk Register.

Environment Hazards

  • All staff are required to care for Hi Five Community Services’ equipment in an appropriate manner and to ensure that it is clean and safe.
  • Broken equipment or furniture, lighting or ventilation should be reported to the Director immediately and removed where possible.
  • Hazardous equipment will be stored in the appropriate places.
  • Repairs that do not present an immediate risk to staff, clients or other stakeholders will be assessed by the Directors and passed on to the appropriate person to repair the problem.

Reporting

  • Incidents relating to any of Hi Five Community Services’ equipment, furniture, lighting and ventilation should be reported in accordance with Hi Five Community Services’ Incident Management Policy and Procedure.

Monitoring and Review

  • This policy and procedure will be reviewed at least annually by Hi Five Community Services’ Management Team. This process will include a review and evaluation of: current practices and service delivery types and locations; the Incident Register; policies and procedures; the Complaints and Grievances Register; and, will incorporate staff, client and other stakeholder’s feedback.
  • Hi Five Community Services’ Continuous Improvement Plan will be used to record and monitor progress of any improvements identified and where relevant feed into Hi Five Community Services’ service planning and delivery processes.

Endorsement Date: 15 Jan 2020

Last Review Date: 10 Jan 2020

Next Review Date: 15 Jan 2021

This policy and procedure will be reviewed at least annually and any proposed changes approved by the Management Team.

fields.label: PART 3. ACCESS TO SUPPORTS

fields.options:
Hi Five Community Services’ Access to Supports Policies and Procedures describe how it enables easy access of services to its clients, their families and carers.

They should be read alongside other parts of our policy pack which cover the ways Hi Five Community Services meets NDIS Commission practice standards.

fields.label: 3.1 ACCESS TO SUPPORTS POLICY AND PROCEDURE

fields.options:
Purpose and Scope

The purpose of this policy and procedure is to demonstrate Hi Five Community Services’ commitment to service access procedures that uphold the right of people to access appropriate services that meet their needs and are provided in a transparent and equitable way.

Legislation, regulations and standards relevant to this policy and procedure include:

  • NDIS Practice Standards and Quality Indicators – Provision of Supports
  • National Disability Insurance Scheme (Provider Registration and Practice Standards) Rules 2018 [F2020C00051]
  • Disability Inclusion Act 2018
  • Australian Human Rights Commission Act 1986 (Cwth)
  • Disability Discrimination Act 1992 (Cwth)
  • Racial Discrimination Act 1975 (Cwth)
  • Sex Discrimination Act 1984 (Cwth)
  • Age Discrimination Act 2004 (Cwth)
  • Privacy Act 1988 (Cwth)

Documents relevant to this policy and procedure include:

  • Hi Five Community Services NDIS Client Charter
  • Hi Five Community Services Feedback, Compliments and Complaints Policy and Procedure
  • Hi Five Community Services Privacy and Confidentiality Policy and Procedure
  • Hi Five Community Services Decision Making and Choice Policy and Procedure
  • Hi Five Community Services Work Health and Safety Policies and Procedures
  • Providing Information, Advice and Referrals Policy and Procedure

This policy and procedure applies to all potential and existing clients for Hi Five Community Services’ disability-specific services, their family members, carers and other supporters.

Definitions

Disability – a sensory, physical or neurological impairment or acquired brain injury or any

combination thereof, which –

  1. is, or is likely to be, permanent; and
  • causes a substantially reduced capacity in at least one of the areas of self care, self-management, mobility or communication; and
  • requires significant ongoing or long term episodic support; and
  • -is not related to ageing; or
  1. an intellectual disability; or
  2. a developmental delay.[17]

For more information on determining if someone has a disability and what that disability may be, see the Disability Inclusion Act 2018.

Policy

  • Hi Five Community Services’ service delivery environment is safe and engaging, physically accessible and responsive to its clients’ support and communication needs.
  • Hi Five Community Services’ screening and eligibility, priority of access and waitlist management is undertaken in a fair, equitable and transparent manner, and in line with Hi Five Community Services’ NDIS Client Charter. Access to services is based on relative need, service capacity, the best interests of people using the service and potential impact on existing service users.

Procedures

  • The Directors (or delegates) are responsible for ensuring staff are familiar with the requirements of this policy and have sufficient skills, knowledge and ability to meet the requirements.
  • The Senior Manager will report to the Management Team on the effectiveness of the entry and referral processes. This is discussed at the Management Team meetings.
  • Client feedback and complaints will be addressed in accordance with Hi Five Community Services’ Feedback, Compliments and Complaints Policy and Procedure.
  • In accordance with Hi Five Community Services’ Privacy and Confidentiality Policy and Procedure, respect for and protection of clients’ privacy and confidentiality will be reinforced on an ongoing basis, verbally and in literature promoting the services offered by the organisation.
  • Where required, clients will be provided with information and support to access a person of their choice, such as an advocate, to assist them to access the service. See Hi Five Community Services’ Decision Making and Choice Policy and Procedure.

Service Environment

  • Hi Five Community Services ensures its service environment is kept clean, hygienic, safe, secure and aesthetically pleasing at all times, through implementing the following:
  • Hi Five Community Services’ Work Health and Safety Policies and Procedures, including fire safety and emergency; safety and security; maintenance and management of equipment, furniture, lighting and ventilation; electrical safety; vehicle safety; physical accessibility; chemical use and storage; infection control; and food storage and preparation;
  • Hi Five Community Services’ Risk Management; Incident Management; Feedback, Compliments and Complaints; and Continuous Improvement Policies and Procedures.
  • Hi Five Community Services’ physical accessibility is ensured through its Physical Accessibility and Work Health and Safety Policy and Procedure. As per this Policy and Procedure, Hi Five Community Services takes a continuous improvement approach to its physical accessibility and encourages clients to use its Feedback, Compliments and Complaints Policy and Procedure to assist it to respond to accessibility needs where required.
  • Hi Five Community Services’ opening hours are 9:00am to 5:00pm Monday to Friday.
  • The Directors (or delegates) will track demand, as well as client and accessibility needs, by monitoring:
  • demographic data: relating to the local community and its needs from Local, State and Federal Government Sources, including ABS data and specific NDIS market data published by the NDIA;
  • unmet need: demographic data (as above), Hi Five Community Services enquiry and waitlist data and feedback from staff, including those involved in local service networks; and
  • opportunities for innovation and improvement: through quarterly review of Hi Five Community Services’ Complaints Register and Continuous Improvement Plan and annual staff and client satisfaction surveys.
  • Information for clients, including Hi Five Community Services signage and client information, will be provided in a variety of formats such as different languages, Easy English, face-to-face or phone explanation by staff, and the use of interpreters and advocates. Specific formats provided will be responsive to demand data (as above) and individual client needs.
  • Hi Five Community Services will provide suitable client resources to accommodate the local population. This will take into account cultural backgrounds, disabilities, age and developmental stage where appropriate. Any premises signage will also be consistent with local population requirements.
  • Hi Five Community Services will develop and implement a Reconciliation Action Plan to ensure it builds strong relationships, respect and opportunities for people from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander backgrounds within Hi Five Community Services.

Service Access

  • The Directors (or delegates) will deal with all enquiries from prospective clients or their supporters about accessing services. If the Directors don’t take the initial enquiry personally, they will contact the person seeking services or their supporter within 1 working day.
  • In their first contact with the person or their supporter, the Directors (or delegates) will assess whether the person requires any support to move through the intake process.
  • The Directors (or delegates) will advise the person of their right to involve a support person in their dealings with Hi Five Community Services.
  • They will also provide information and support for the person to access a person of their choice, such as an advocate, to assist them to interact with the service (see Hi Five Community Services’ Decision Making and Choice Policy and Procedure).
  • Where physical access issues are identified, the Directors will consider whether Hi Five Community Services is accessible for the person, and if not, how it could be made accessible.
  • Where a language or cultural barrier is identified, the Directors (or delegates) will engage an interpreter or an appropriate external agency to support the person. See Hi Five Community Services’ Service Delivery and Participation Policy and Procedure.
  • The Directors (or delegates) will book an Intake Interview with the person within 5 working days of their initial contact with them or sooner if the person’s needs are considered urgent.
  • The Directors (or delegates) will conduct all Intake Interviews. They will provide the person with information about:
  • entry and exit procedures;
  • eligibility and priority of access requirements;
  • conditions that may apply to service provision; and
  • fees.
  • To be eligible to receive Hi Five Community Services’ disability-specific services, a person must meet the following eligibility criteria. The person:
  • has one or more identified intellectual, cognitive, neurological, sensory or physical impairments that are, or are likely to be, permanent; or
  • has one or more identified impairments that are attributable to a psychiatric condition and are, or are likely to be, permanent; or
  • is a child who has developmental delay.
  • Consideration must also be given to the person’s Priority of Access by examining:
  • the person’s relative need compared to others who receive or want to receive Hi Five Community Services’ services;
  • any special additional needs of the person, and where relevant, their family, carer or other supporters;
  • the extent to which Hi Five Community Services can contribute to those needs being met;
  • the resources available within Hi Five Community Services to meet the person’s needs;
  • other services the person receives and how Hi Five Community Services’ services will complement those and contribute to improved outcomes for the person; and
  • the best interests of the person.
  • Where relevant, the interview will take into account information already provided about the person in their NDIS Plan.
  • The Directors (or delegates) will provide the person with:
  • a Hi Five Community Services Participant Induction Handbook (outlining Hi Five Community Services’ entry and exit procedures and appeal processes (see service refusal, below), priority of access requirements, waitlist procedures, fees, hours of operation, booking procedures, conditions that apply to service delivery, rights and responsibilities, privacy and confidentiality, and feedback, compliments and complaints processes; and
  • Hi Five Community Services’ NDIS Client Charter, Privacy Statement and Feedback, Compliments and Complaints brochure.
  • Where required, the Directors (or delegates) will provide this information in an alternative format such as a different language, Easy English, detailed verbal explanation or the use of interpreters and advocates.
  • The Directors (or delegates) will contact the person or their supporter within 1 working day of the Intake Interview to advise them of the outcome[18]. Notification will be provided by phone and or email.
  • Where the client is offered services and accepts, see Hi Five Community Services’ NDIS Assessment, Planning and Review Policy and Procedure.

Non-acceptance

  • Where a person is offered services but chooses not to accept the offer, staff will respect this choice.
  • The Directors (or delegates) will encourage the person to contact Hi Five Community Services should they change their mind, noting that they may need to be placed on Hi Five Community Services’ waitlist if the service has no capacity to provide services at the time they do recontact.

Service Refusal

  • Where services cannot be provided, the person will be provided with a clear reason based on Hi Five Community Services’ eligibility criteria, Priority of Access requirements or waiting list processes.
  • Hi Five Community Services may refuse to offer a person services where:
  • they do not meet Hi Five Community Services’ eligibility requirements;
  • other potential clients are assessed as a higher priority based on Hi Five Community Services’ Priority of Access Considerations;
  • Hi Five Community Services does not have the capacity to cater to additional clients;
  • Hi Five Community Services does not have the resources to cater to the specific needs of the person.
  • A person who meets Hi Five Community Services’ eligibility requirements and cannot be offered a service due to lack of capacity, can elect to be placed on Hi Five Community Services’ Waiting List. The person will be advised of the possible waiting time before services might become available.
  • In either case, the person will be assisted with referrals and support to access alternative services, as per Hi Five Community Services’ Providing Information, Advice and Referrals Policy and Procedure.

Waiting List processes

  • The Directors (or delegates) will contact people on its Waiting List at least every three months to:
  • advise them of their current status;
  • check whether they want to remain on the list;
  • provide referrals to other service providers if required; and
  • advise the estimated wait time remaining.
  • To keep Waiting List size and wait times to a minimum, at the Directors’ discretion, additional services will be offered where justified by demand and resources allow.

Appeal

  • Any person refused services has the right to appeal the Directors’ decision. Appeals should be directed in writing to Hi Five Community Services’ Directors and a final decision will be made by the Management Team.
  • If required, staff will provide support for a person to make an appeal, by either transcribing their feedback for the Directors’ (or delegate’s) review or referring the person to interpreter or advocacy services.
  • Those not successful in their appeal will be provided written advice to this effect. For procedures for those who successfully appeal, see Hi Five Community Services’ NDIS Assessment, Planning and Review Policy and Procedure.
  • If a person is unhappy with outcome of their appeal, they will be directed to Hi Five Community Services’ complaints process. As per Hi Five Community Services’ Feedback, Compliments and Complaints Policy and Procedure, information on Hi Five Community Services’ complaints process can be provided in a variety of formats if required, including support to access interpreters or advocates if necessary.

Alternative supports

  • Hi Five Community Services will work collaboratively with all people refused services and (with consent) their supporters, to identify what alternative services and referrals could best meet their needs.
  • With the client's consent, relevant information will be provided by Hi Five Community Services to new service providers to support the client's seamless transition. Where required, Hi Five Community Services staff will also meet with staff of alternative providers to facilitate a smooth transition for the client.

Continuous improvement

  • Hi Five Community Services will maintain a record of people who have been refused a service, summarising reasons for their being found ineligible or, if found eligible, reasons for being placed on Hi Five Community Services’ Waiting List.
  • Access, service refusal and referral information will be tracked in Hi Five Community Services’ client management system to inform Hi Five Community Services’ continuous improvement.

Monitoring and Review

  • This Policy and Procedure will be reviewed at least annually by Hi Five Community Services’ Management Team and incorporate staff, client and other stakeholder feedback. Clients and service networks will be advised of any changes.
  • Hi Five Community Services’ Continuous Improvement Plan will be used to record and monitor progress of any improvements identified and feed into Hi Five Community Services’ service planning and delivery processes.
  • Hi Five Community Services’ annual service delivery and satisfaction surveys will assess:
  • client and other stakeholder awareness of Hi Five Community Services’ access procedures;
  • client and other stakeholder satisfaction with Hi Five Community Services’ physical access, service access procedures and management of service refusal and appeals regarding access; and
  • whether clients are satisfied with the service environment, service delivery and referral and support to access other services.
  • Hi Five Community Services’ six-monthly Service Delivery and Planning days and activities will include clients and stakeholders where relevant and assess:
  • Whether Hi Five Community Services’ eligibility criteria are reflected in its clients; and
  • Feedback provided by and to clients and potential clients around access and refusal and whether the information provided to clients is appropriate and effective.

Endorsement Date: 15 Jan 2020

Last Review Date: 10 Jan 2020

Next Review Date: 15 Jan 2021

This policy and procedure will be reviewed at least annually and changes endorsed by the Management Team.

fields.label: 3.2 PROVIDING INFORMATION, ADVICE AND REFERRAL POLICY AND PROCEDURE

fields.options:
Purpose and Scope

The purpose of this policy and procedure is to ensure Hi Five Community Services’ clients and other stakeholders access services most appropriate to their needs through timely and responsive service integration and referral.

Legislation, regulations and standards relevant to this policy and procedure include:

  • National Disability Insurance Scheme Act 2013
  • National Disability Insurance Scheme (Protection and Disclosure of Information - Commissioner) Rules 2018 [F2018L00635]
  • NDIS Practice Standards and Quality Indicators – Provision of Supports
  • User Rights Principles 2014
  • Disability Inclusion Act 2018

Documents relevant to this policy and procedure include:

  • Hi Five Community Services NDIS Client Charter
  • Hi Five Community Services Information Management Policy and Procedure
  • Hi Five Community Services NDIS Service Access Policy and Procedure
  • Hi Five Community Services NDIS Assessment, Planning and Review Policy and Procedure
  • Hi Five Community Services Decision Making and Choice Policy and Procedure
  • Hi Five Community Services Privacy and Confidentiality Policy and Procedure
  • Hi Five Community Services Feedback, Compliments and Complaints Policy and Procedure
  • Hi Five Community Services Referral Database

This policy and procedure applies to all potential and existing clients for Carers for services, their family members, carers and other supporters as well as other Hi Five Community Services stakeholders.

Types of Referral

Passive – The person is given contact information for appropriate services so they can make their own contact at a time that best suits them.

Facilitated referral – The person is helped to access the other service, for example, Hi Five Community Services makes an appointment with the other service on the person’s behalf, asks the other service to make contact with the person or a caller is transferred to the other service.

Active referral - Hi Five Community Services, with the person’s consent, provides the organisation to which it is referring the person with information that it has collected about the person or with its professional assessment of the person’s needs.

Cold referral – A caller is transferred to another service, without any immediate communication between Hi Five Community Services and the other service.

Warm Referral - A ‘live’ three way conversation in the presence of the client (whether face to face or by telephone) in which Hi Five Community Services introduces the client, explains what has already been done to assist the client and why the client is being referred. 

Policy

  • Hi Five Community Services works proactively as part of a broader service delivery network, which enhances its own service delivery and provides its clients with appropriate referrals and services that meet their needs.
  • Hi Five Community Services will inform the community, potential clients and other services about its services and access requirements through active engagement strategies that encourage and facilitate client and stakeholder participation.
  • Where possible, people (including clients leaving the service or people unable to access Hi Five Community Services’ services) will be referred using facilitated, warm or active referral processes in accordance with the Information Sharing Guidelines for Registered Community Services in SA.

Procedures

Service Network Engagement

  • Hi Five Community Services’ Management Team will build strong relationships with local government and non-government providers, agencies, health services and advocacy services and participate in relevant local networks, to increase service and referral options for its clients and other stakeholders.
  • Hi Five Community Services’ Management Team will build strong relationships with relevant Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander (ATSI) and culturally and linguistically diverse (CALD) services to support it to identify and meet clients’ needs and goals, as well as contribute to more coordinated service provision, better use of resources and improved outcomes for clients and communities. This includes active involvement with ATSI and CALD communities and services, such as participation in community events, collaborative service provision and referrals.
  • The Management Team will collaborate with local ATSI and CALD service providers to assist culturally sensitive service delivery, ensure staff are adequately trained and sensitive to the specific cultural needs of the service area (including in the development of referral practices) and generally facilitate participation of stakeholders from these backgrounds in the service and community.
  • The Management team will also build strong relationships with other service providers that support people with special needs, , to contribute to more coordinated service provision, better use of resources and improved outcomes for clients. The Management team will collaborate with these services to ensure service provision is meaningful and sensitive to people with special needs, and staff are adequately trained.
  • Where applicable, Hi Five Community Services will develop clear protocols with other service providers (including medical officers and health professionals), such as memorandums of understanding or other forms of agreement, which in outline relationships and delineate the roles and responsibilities of collaborating agencies. The Directors will be responsible for establishing, reviewing and modifying such agreements.
  • Directors (or delegates) will be encouraged to attend interagency meetings as a means of linking with other service providers and to inform them of client service and referral options.
  • Hi Five Community Services will retain records of service network involvement, such as meeting minutes and communications, in accordance with Hi Five Community Services’ Information Management Policy and Procedure, to inform continuous improvement.
  • The Directors (or delegate) will review Hi Five Community Services’ participation in service and referral networks on an annual basis to ensure the arrangements in place are the best use of Hi Five Community Services’ resources and are providing the best possible outcomes for Hi Five Community Services’ stakeholders.

Service Promotion

  • The Directors (or delegates) will ensure Hi Five Community Services is listed on relevant directories, including through the ‘Find Registered Service Providers’ tool on the NDIS website
  • Hi Five Community Services will distribute information about its services in appropriate formats to local government and non-government providers and agencies in the organisation’s geographical service area.

Referral and Information Sharing

  • Hi Five Community Services will prominently display information (such as brochures) in its foyer regarding alternative services and local community participation options for clients and other stakeholders. Where possible (noting that the bulk of this collateral will be provided by other providers) information will be provided in a variety of formats, including staff explanation where necessary. Where clients are not accessing services at Hi Five Community Services’ premises, staff can provide them with brochures or information that may be of interest to them.
  • The Directors (or delegates) will maintain a comprehensive Referrals Database, which will be continuously reviewed and built upon by all delivery staff.
  • The Directors (or delegates) will respond to referrals and requests for its services in accordance with its NDIS Service Access Policy and Procedure Referrals required as part of Hi Five Community Services’ support of a client will be dealt with in accordance with this and other relevant Hi Five Community Services policy and procedure.
  • Hi Five Community Services will work collaboratively with all people refused services or leaving Hi Five Community Services, and their supporters, to identify what alternative services and referrals could best meet their needs.
  • In all cases, referrals to other services will be made within 2 working days, except where the situation is urgent. Urgent referrals should be made within 2 hours (or immediately where the person is at risk of immediate harm).
  • Staff making referrals must have an accurate knowledge of the services provided by other agencies and actively contribute to the continuous improvement of Hi Five Community Services’ Referral Database.
  • Staff will provide referrals with empathy and respect for the person, a non-judgemental attitude and sensitivity to their needs. 
  • Where required, people will be provided with information and support to access a person of their choice, such as an advocate, to assist them to interact with Hi Five Community Services Directors (or delegates) and other services. See Hi Five Community Services’ Decision Making and Choice Policy and Procedure.
  • When providing referrals, staff will take into consideration:
  • the person’s most pressing needs (including those relating to health);
  • safety issues and whether a referral will compromise the person’s safety;
  • the level of distress experienced by the person (e.g. it may be necessary to calm the person or seek the support of a more senior staff member before referring them on to other services);
  • the needs of children, vulnerable people and people with complex needs or at high risk;
  • the person’s age, ability, gender, sexual identity, culture, religion, special needs, spirituality and language and communication needs; and
  • other services the person is already receiving and from where.
  • Staff must be aware of possible barriers that a person may experience in using another service and, where feasible and appropriate, work with them to find ways to overcome these barriers. Barriers may include:
  • lack of information about services and what is available;
  • lack of client capacity or interest in taking up a referral;
  • waiting lists that are too long to meet the client’s needs;
  • difficulties advocating for their needs and/or preferences;
  • cost;
  • lack of child care;
  • cultural or language barriers;
  • difficulties in contacting clients (e.g. lack of phone services);
  • family ties;
  • lack of anonymity in small communities;
  • lack of interpreters;
  • lack of services particularly in rural and regional areas; and
  • lack of transport options.
  • Staff will be assisted to support individuals with special or complex needs through ongoing formal and on-the-job training and professional development opportunities.
  • Staff will acknowledge and address any concerns and explain the reasons why a particular referral has been made.
  • Where more than one service may assist a person, it is appropriate to provide them with information about the range of services available and give them choice over which particular service or services they want to use. In doing so, staff may need to provide some guidance on any special conditions for using a service. It is important to refer people to the most appropriate service at the right time and avoid a ‘merry-go-round’ of referrals.
  • Staff should use facilitated, warm or active referral processes where feasible, especially for clients who are likely to have trouble using other services without assistance. 
  • Where a referral is a passive or cold referral, staff should provide sufficient information to the person to help make the referral successful.
  • Where appropriate, staff may also follow up with the person to ensure the referral was effective. 
  • Where required, information about alternative services, Hi Five Community Services’ referral process and Hi Five Community Services’ feedback and complaints processes will be provided to people in alternative formats that facilitate their understanding. Information about Hi Five Community Services’ referral processes and information sharing provisions will be included in its Hi Five Community Services Participant Induction Handbook and provided where required by staff, including during service delivery.
  • Where a person is not satisfied with referrals provided or the integration of supports provided by Hi Five Community Services with other services, they will be directed to Hi Five Community Services’ feedback and complaints processes.
  • Service access and refusal and referral information will be tracked in Hi Five Community Services’ client management system and on client files. Records will include the timeframes within which incoming referrals were actioned or outgoing referrals made.

Information Sharing Provisions

  • When sharing a person’s information with another service, staff must:
  • give priority to a person’s best interests, including consideration of the need to maintain a person’s health, protect them from harm, protect their rights and promote their development;
  • where they are not specifically authorised to share information by the Children, Youth and Families Act 2005, only share information as authorised by privacy legislation (see Hi Five Community Services’ Privacy and Confidentiality Policy and Procedure);
  • seek consent, where this is possible, before sharing information and where this does not place the person or any other person at risk;
  • exercise professional judgment – use their professional skills, knowledge and experience – in deciding what action to take in regard to a vulnerable person; and
  • consult with a senior staff member where they are unsure of what to do.

Monitoring and Review

  • This Policy and Procedure will be reviewed at least annually by Hi Five Community Services’ Management Team. This process will include a review and evaluation of: current practices; the Incident Register; the Complaints and Grievances Register; and, will incorporate staff, client and other stakeholder’s feedback.
  • Hi Five Community Services’ Continuous Improvement Plan will be used to record and monitor progress of any improvements identified and feed into Hi Five Community Services’ service planning and delivery processes.
  • Processes and materials for communicating Hi Five Community Services’ eligibility criteria, priority of access requirements and waiting list procedures, as well as service entry and exit processes, will be updated upon review and update of Hi Five Community Services’ NDIS Service Access Policy and Procedure. Relevant referral networks will also be advised.
  • Service access and refusal and referral information will be tracked in Hi Five Community Services’ client management system. Information about referral pathways will be used to inform Hi Five Community Services’ continuous improvement.
  • On a six-monthly basis, Hi Five Community Services will assess its performance against its benchmarks for responding to requests for information and actioning referrals, to ensure they are dealt with in a timely manner that supports the immediacy of the needs of the person enquiring.
  • While delivery staff are responsible for actively updating Hi Five Community Services’ Referral Database on an ongoing basis, the Directors will formally review the Database every six months to ensure the currency and relevance of the information it contains.
  • Annual review of this Policy and Procedure will include staff, client and other stakeholder feedback and incorporate:
  • client file audits, to assess alignment between documented processes and actual practice;
  • service involvement and links with ATSI, CALD and other special needs communities and services; 
  • a review of Hi Five Community Services’ service network and referral processes to service planning and delivery; and
  • a review of feedback from staff, clients and other stakeholder on their satisfaction with Hi Five Community Services’ service integration and referral management.

Endorsement Date: 15 Jan 2020

Last Review Date: 10 Jan 2020

Next Review Date: 15 Jan 2021

This policy and procedure will be reviewed at least annually and changes endorsed by the Management Team.

fields.label: 3.3 SUPPORT PLANNING AND REVIEW (Co-Ordination of Supports) POLICY AND PROCEDURE

fields.options:
Purpose and Scope

The purpose of this policy and procedure is to set out the approach Hi Five Community Services will take to assessment, planning and review in respect to client support plans, once a person has been offered and accepted Hi Five Community Services’ services. This policy applies to all clients including for whom we are doing Co-ordination of Supports level 1 and level 2.

Legislation, regulations and standards relevant to this policy and procedure include:

  • National Disability Insurance Scheme Act 2013
  • NDIS Practice Standards and Quality Indicators – Provision of Supports
  • National Disability Insurance Scheme (Provider Registration and Practice Standards) Rules 2018 [F2020C00051]
  • The NDIS Terms of Business and Guide to Suitability
  • Disability Inclusion Act 2018
  • Australian Consumer Law
  • Age Discrimination Act 2004 (Cwth)
  • Australian Human Rights Commission Act 1986 (Cwth)
  • Disability Discrimination Act 1992 (Cwth)
  • Racial Discrimination Act 1975 (Cwth)
  • Sex Discrimination Act 1984 (Cwth)

Documents relevant to this policy and procedure include:

  • Hi Five Community Services NDIS Client Charter
  • Hi Five Community Services NDIS Service Agreement Templates
  • Hi Five Community Services Providing Information, Advice and Referrals Policy and Procedure
  • Hi Five Community Services Information Management Policy and Procedure
  • Hi Five Community Services NDIS Service Access Policy and Procedure
  • Hi Five Community Services Decision Making and Choice Policy and Procedure
  • Hi Five Community Services Privacy and Confidentiality Policy and Procedure
  • Hi Five Community Services Feedback, Compliments and Complaints Policy and Procedure
  • Hi Five Community Services Referral Database
  • Starlight CoS Report
  • NDIS Progress Report (8 weeks and 9 months)

This policy and procedure applies to all clients of Hi Five Community Services’ disability-specific services, including Coordination of Supports clients, their family members, carers and other supporters.

Definitions

Planning - a process to enable people with a disability to explore their needs, goals and aspirations and the ways they can be supported to achieve these. Planning will have a different focus for each person.[19]

Co-ordination of Supports – a funded NDIS support (part of Capacity Building) in clients NDIS plan, which allows the client to employ a support co-ordinator. The role of the support co-ordinator is to explain the NDIS plan to the participant, link client to service providers for services listed in participants NDIS plan, work with participant on achieving their goals and planning future goals, help with the plan, manage service provider relationship, manage any complaints etc.

Policy

  • This policy and procedure aligns with the Planning requirements as set out in the Disability Inclusion Act 2018 (Division 3), and the principles of the NDIS Act 2013 (Cwth) of participation, choice and control, engaging as equal partners in decisions and including families, carers and other significant people.
  • Hi Five Community Services will provide its clients with limited assistance with planning, including regarding its own service delivery and through providing advice, information and referrals.
  • Extensive assistance with planning is provided by Hi Five Community Services to deliver planning or Co-ordination of supports as one of our functions and with the expertise to develop informal, community and disability-specific responses. See Hi Five Community Services’ Referral Database for relevant contacts.
  • Deliver person centred co-ordination of supports, and offer clients choice and control over their NDIS plans.

Procedures

  • Directors (or delegates) involved in assessment, planning and review activities will be trained in and capable of implementing:
  • active engagement and early intervention strategies, including with families;
  • strength-based planning, assessment and review;
  • holistic and collaborative approaches to service delivery; and
  • capacity building of families and carers.
  • The clients will be offered full choice and control when planning their supports and co-ordinating supports, linking clients to service providers and during on-going service delivery. If the client is not satisfied with the services, they will be offered alternative choices and will not be locked to a service provider they are not satisfied with.
  • With client’s wishes and permission, we will include client’s family, friends, and chosen community in the service delivery planning and support clients to engage with their family, friends and chosen community.
  • All documentation relating to assessment, planning and review will be maintained on client files and tracked in Hi Five Community Services’ client management system.
  • For all assessments, planning and review activities, the Directors (or delegates) will discuss clients’ rights and responsibilities with them. They will confirm clients’ understanding verbally, using an interpreter or advocate where required.
  • The Directors (or delegates) will advise the person of their right to involve a support person in their dealings with Hi Five Community Services.
  • Where required, clients will be provided with information and support to access a person of their choice, such as an advocate, to assist them to access the service. See Hi Five Community Services’ Decision Making and Choice Policy and Procedure.
  • In accordance with Hi Five Community Services’ Privacy and Confidentiality Policy and Procedure, respect for and protection of clients’ privacy and confidentiality will be reinforced on an ongoing basis, verbally and in literature promoting the services offered by the organisation.
  • Where physical access issues are identified, the Directors (or delegates) will consider whether the service is accessible for the person, and if not, how it could be made accessible.
  • Where a language or cultural barrier is identified, the Directors (or delegates) will engage an interpreter or an appropriate external agency to support the person. The client will also be offered written information in a language most understandable to them.
  • The client will be offered a minimum of two weeks period for them to decide at any stage of supports provision, including assessment, planning, provision review and exit for any decision to be made. In this time, they can ask questions, make enquiries etc. to make decision.
  • If necessary and with the client or their supporter/s consent, other parties such as service providers who deliver existing or complementary services to clients will be included in assessment, planning and review activities.
  • The Directors (or delegates) will take into account the client’s wishes in regards to accepting or rejecting particular support options.

Assessment

  • Following their Intake Interview, where a client is offered services and accepts, the Director/s (or delegates) will work with the client and their supporter/s to assess their needs, develop and agree upon a Service Agreement.
  • The Director/s (or delegates) will meet with the client and their supporter/s within 5 working days of their acceptance, or sooner if able, for an Assessment and Planning Interview.
  • The Director/s (or delegates) will conduct all Assessment and Planning Interviews.
  • The assessment will take into account:
  • the client’s needs (including health, wellbeing and safety needs), goals and longer-term aspirations;
  • the supports that can be provided by Hi Five Community Services to meet those;
  • the client’s preferred links to family, friendships and other support networks;
  • the client’s and their supporters’ age, ability, gender, sexual identity, culture, religion or spirituality;
  • any barriers to community participation and strategies that could be put in place to help clients overcome them; and
  • how, when, and where the client requires the supports to be delivered.
  • Where possible, support provided by Hi Five Community Services should:
  • ensure clients develop, maintain and strengthen independence, problem solving, social and self-care skills appropriate to their age, developmental stage and cultural circumstances; and
  • help clients to take control of and responsibility for their choices and enhance their autonomy, independence and community participation.
  • Where relevant, the interview will take into account information already provided about the person in their NDIS Plan.
  • Where required, the Directors (or delegates) will identify and provide referrals and linkages to other services and activities that will enhance the client’s community participation and provide support and assistance to help them access these.
  • Referral possibilities include, but are not limited to: training, employment, education, health, wellness, recreation, leisure, cultural and community services, activities and events, as well as public transport and affordable housing options.
  • Referrals to alternative services will be provided in accordance with Hi Five Community Services’ Providing Information, Advice and Referrals Policy and Procedure.

Planning

  • The Directors (or delegates) will work with the client and their supporter/s to formalise the supports to be provided by Hi Five Community Services in a Service Agreement. Hi Five Community Services’ Service Agreement Templates can be tailored to the individual needs of each client.
  • As a support co-ordinator Hi Five Community Services will use the assessments of each client to plan individualized supports for each client. We will individually match the clients to service providers that meet clients requirements.
  • The support- coordinator will complete the 8 week progress report and 9 months progress reports and send to NDIS LAC/ Planner as required.

Service Agreement

When doing service agreements with clients, Hi Five Community Services will make sure to collaborate with each participant to develop the service agreement which establishes expectations, explains the supports to be delivered, and specifies any conditions attached to the delivery of supports, including why these conditions are attached.

Each participant is supported to understand their service agreement and conditions using the language, mode of communication and terms that the participant is most likely to understand.

Each participant will be given a signed hard copy or soft copy as they require upon signing of the agreement.

The Service Agreement will include:

  • the supports that will be provided;
  • the cost of those supports;
  • how, when, and where the client requires the supports to be delivered;
  • the period for when the client requires the supports to be provided;
  • when and how the Service Agreement will be reviewed;
  • how the client and Hi Five Community Services will deal with any problems or questions that arise, including complaint handling and dispute resolution;
  • what the client’s and their supporter’s responsibilities are under the Service Agreement;
  • what Hi Five Community Services’ responsibilities are under the Service Agreement; and
  • what notice is needed for the client or Hi Five Community Services to change or end the Service Agreement and how this is done.
  • Service Agreements will be prepared within no more than 7 days of the client commencing to regularly access Hi Five Community Services’ services, and ideally by a service benchmark timeframe of 5 days.
  • The Directors (or delegates) must ensure the client (and their supporter/s) understands their plan, or are supported to understand it, and provide the client a copy. A copy will also be kept on the client’s file and key elements captured in Hi Five Community Services’ client management system.
  • The supports can be provided to the client in absence of the Service Agreement if the client choses not to have a service agreement. Where the participant chooses not to have an agreement, a record is made of the circumstances under which the participant did not receive a copy of their agreement.
  • When providing Support Coordination supports to the client, the support coordinator will assist the client in signing service agreements with other service providers and explain to the client the service agreements as needed.

Review

  • The Directors (or delegates) with the relevant stakeholders will review the provision of supports for each client every 6 months with the client and their supporter/s.
  • Flexibility will be provided in regards to the timing of review assessments, based on clients’ needs and wishes.
  • Reviews will include:
  • the client’s needs (including health, wellbeing and safety needs), goals and longer-term aspirations;
  • the client’s progress towards addressing their needs and achieving their goals;
  • recognition and celebration of the client’s progress; and
  • the client’s and their supporters’ age, ability, gender, sexual identity, culture, religion or spirituality;
  • the client’s preferred links to family, friendships and other support networks;
  • any barriers to community participation and strategies that could be put in place to help clients overcome them; and
  • whether there needs to be a change to the supports provided.
  • Where possible, support provided to clients by Hi Five Community Services should:
  • support them to develop, maintain and strengthen independence, problem solving, social and self-care skills appropriate to their age, developmental stage and cultural circumstances; and
  • help clients to take control of and responsibility for their choices and enhance their autonomy, independence and community participation.
  • Reviews will take into account information in the client’s NDIS Plan (if applicable).
  • If changes to supports or their delivery are required, a Change of Booking form will be completed by the client or their supporter/s and the Directors and the Change of booking form will be attached to the client’s Service Agreement.
  • If the client wishes to change their service delivery outside of the six-monthly review cycle, they can request a review or complete a Change of Booking form with the Directors (or delegates).

Monitoring and Review

  • This Policy and Procedure will be reviewed at least annually by Hi Five Community Services’ Management Team and incorporate staff, client and other stakeholder feedback.
  • Hi Five Community Services’ Continuous Improvement Plan will be used to record and monitor progress of any improvements identified and feed into Hi Five Community Services’ service planning and delivery processes.
  • Hi Five Community Services’ annual client satisfaction surveys will assess client:
  • satisfaction with supports provided;
  • satisfaction with the relevance and quality of referrals and connections provided by Hi Five Community Services staff; and
  • awareness of, access to and experience of supports provided to enable them to maintain and enhance links with other people and organisations.

Withdrawal of services

  • Hi Five Community Services supports clients in making decisions and choices as part of enabling clients and making them more independent. Hi Five Community Services will not withdraw services to client solely on the basis of a dignity of risk choice that has been made the client.
  • The decision to withdraw services must be approved by the director 100% of times.
  • The client will be given agreed notice time (as set out in service agreement) and transition support to a new service provider in case of withdrawing services.

Endorsement Date: 15 Jan 2020

Last Review Date: 10 Jan 2020

Next Review Date: 15 Jan 2021

This policy and procedure will be reviewed at least annually and changes endorsed by the Management Team.

fields.label: 3.4 RESPONSIVE SUPPORT PROVISION POLICY AND PROCEDURE

fields.options:
Purpose and Scope

The organisation adopts a “Person Centred Planning” approach to underpin its service delivery and support its participants to achieve their goals and get as much as possible out of the service they receive.

It emphasises not only person-centred planning but also person-centred thinking and person-centred approaches. The focus of this model can be described as “nothing about the person without the person”, meaning to involve the person directly and as much as possible in the planning, provision and review of their supports, as well as any other aspect of their service and the organisation.

Alongside that is the belief that the lack of opportunities people with a disability face are more around the barriers society places on them, rather than their own disability. Accordingly, people should not be looked on by their disability, but should be encouraged to reach any dream or desire they may have, and their supports should be focused around both building their skills but also reducing any societal barriers in their way.

Hence there is much more focus on employment, further education, independent travel, and flexible models of semi-independent accommodation in the sector at present. Just as important and necessary is promoting the wider family and social networks of participants to be involved in their supports and their lives, as a wider collaborative approach has always proved more successful in achieving one’s goals.

Legislation, regulations and standards relevant to this policy and procedure include:

  • National Disability Insurance Scheme Act 2013
  • National Disability Insurance Scheme (Provider Registration and Practice Standards) Rules 2018 [F2020C00051]
  • Disability Inclusion Act 2018
  • NDIS Practice Standards and Quality Indicators – Rights and Responsibilities

Policy

The organisation believes in a holistic approach in providing disability care. Our organisations Person Centred Plan meeting invites the families or friends of the participant. This is an opportunity for our staff to engage with the client and their families. The PCP template has a section on family & friend’s interests / occupation; this information will help us in understanding the availability of the families and their interests in specific activities we can engage them in.

As a policy guideline at the organisation, we engage participant and their family members in taking all the major decisions related to the care and support of the participant. This will result in families being advocating for the participants as well as enhancing participants links with their families and friends.

Communication in client’s preferred language

We respect the right of the client to communicate in their preferred language. In the clients intake assessment, client or their legal nominee will be asked of their preferred language for verbal and written communication. Whichever language they prefer will be adapted in service delivery to the client as well as in providing them information and resources in their preferred language.

Procedures

The participant should be involved / in control of the planning process as much as possible

The person-centred plans should be one year in duration, must be formally reviewed at the six month midway point, and new plans developed on expiry of the old plan.

As part of preparation in developing new plans, all other participants assessments must be reviewed with management and relevant stakeholders, and updated as required.

The procedure thus ensures as standard practice all plans, and assessments are reviewed at least annually. Outside of this plans and assessments are reviewed as required, on a case by case basis, e.g. if shorter timeframe is agreed by professionals involved, the participant requests it, the participants needs / supports change etc.

When setting up goals, the focus should be in the participant being supported to learn new independent living skills, problem solving techniques and related skills development to allow the participant to engage in the above activities with as much independence as possible.

Staff will support the participant to access any aids, equipment, assessments (e.g. OT, speech, behavioural), or related supports to assist them to build up these skills, including government sponsored courses provided by registered training organisations (i.e. RTO certified / non-certified skills development courses .

The person-centred planning template is divided into sections, and the above points noted above are covered in the various sections of the template, as prompts for participants and keyworkers to give consideration of these areas when developing the plan, and setting S.M.A.R.T. goals for the participant

This procedure outlines the person-centred planning process at the organisation, and contains key themes relevant to this topic, in particular.

- Keyworkers are to develop person centred plans (PCP’s), run meetings, monitor and review plan goals, and evaluate them, all with the full / maximum involvement of the participant, letting the participant lead the process as much as possible

- Likewise, with the participants consent, the PCP process should similarly involve the families and wider circle of support as much involvement in the development, implementation and review of plans, and notes the keyworkers role in ensuring this is occurring

- Keyworkers are to support participants to access an independent advocate if they choose to do so, or if they do not want / cannot have family members present

- That unless agreed to by the participant (and management) all plans will be for a duration of one year, with a mid-year review 6 month into the plan

- All plans will follow the organisations PCP template, which captures additional information such as general health, strengths and weaknesses, interests and fears, long terms goals etc.

- All plans should contain information on the current goals the participant wants to work on, and the specific supports the organisation will provide to help the participant meet those goals

- All goals must be Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Realistic and Time scaled (S.M.A.R.T)

- All plans should contain strategies for how participants will be supported to reach their goals

- All plans will contain information on the participants age, religious, ethnic, gender, cultural and any other practices / observances, and how the organisation will support, respect or observe these in all supports provided to the participant. The development of goals and associated actions must also reflect and take account of these differences

- All stakeholders, including the participant, are to be provided copies of their completed plans, in a format that they can best understand

- There must be ongoing assessment and other forms of evidence collected to monitor the participants progress against their goals

- community access and the active involvement by participants in community activities and opportunities

- the development of a broad range of independent living skills

- access to further education and vocational opportunities

- training in work skills development and access to work opportunities

- the development and maintaining of friendships and circles of support

- strategies around maintaining and improving their health and wellbeing

- assessment and support to overcome any barriers the participant may face in accessing above, with a particular focus on occupational therapy assessment, speech therapy assessment and communication, and behavioural assessment and therapy.
